articles.title: EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: This document appears to be an introductory or cover page for an "EPHEMERIS" from June 1983, likely associated with the organization SJAA. It features a black and white astronomical photograph showcasing a nebula or cosmic cloud formation against a starry background.

articles.title: CALENDAR
articles.summary: This document presents a calendar of astronomical and organizational events scheduled for June and July. It details various activities including multiple star parties (both indoor and outdoor), board meetings, a general membership meeting featuring annual elections, and an annual picnic. Specific dates, locations, and times are provided for these community and astronomy-related gatherings.

articles.title: FOR SALE
articles.summary: The document primarily features a "for sale" advertisement for a C-8 telescope in like-new condition with various accessories, priced at $800 or best offer. It also contains detailed information about "EPHEMERIS," the monthly publication of the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), including submission guidelines for articles and photos. Additionally, the page lists contact information for the SJAA president, treasurer, and board of directors, noting the June cover image as the Triffid Nebula.

articles.title: BY DENNI FRERICHS
articles.summary: April was a busy month for the astronomy club, highlighted by a successful Astronomy Day on the 22nd, despite a late start to the observing season and challenging weather. The main event at Great America, a last-minute venue change, saw volunteers engaging hundreds of people with telescopes even through heavy rain, leading to invitations for future events. Concurrently, another successful Astronomy Day event was held at a local elementary school, attracting over 100 participants.

articles.title: AUCTION REPORT
articles.summary: This auction report details an event held on April 30th, which attracted over 125 attendees, including 82 registered bidders. A significant increase from the previous year, the auction featured 411 registered items.

articles.title: SJAA PICNICâ€”JULY 23
articles.summary: The article details the success of the third annual SJAA Auction, which raised over $1000 with increased attendance and numerous volunteers. It also announces the upcoming annual club picnic on July 23rd at Portal Park, featuring officer installation, the Dr. A.B. Gregory Award, and a potluck BBQ. Additionally, the piece includes a farewell to member Jeff Horne and an announcement of the president's resignation.

articles.title: BY JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: Jim Van Nuland provides updated predictions for Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) transit times, based on recent observations from California after skies cleared. He notes that early predictions were inaccurate and offers a table of corrected GRS meridian transit times, adjusted for PDT, aspect, phase, and light time. The article also includes practical observing tips for amateur astronomers, detailing the GRS's current appearance (light yellow/pink, more contrasty) and recommending equipment and techniques for successful viewing.

articles.title: STS-7 SCHEDULED FOR JUNE 18 LAUNCH
articles.summary: The STS-7 mission aboard the Space Shuttle Challenger is scheduled for launch on June 18, 1983, carrying a crew of five astronauts, including the first American woman in space, Sally Ride. The mission will deploy two communication satellites, Canada's Anik C2 and Indonesia's Palpa B-1, and conduct several scientific experiments including the OSTA 2 project and the German SPAS satellite.

articles.title: COSMONAUTS FAIL TO RENDEZVOUS
articles.summary: The Soviet Soyuz T-8 mission failed in its attempt to rendezvous with the Salute 7 space station. After two days in space, the mission was aborted and returned to Earth on April 22.

articles.title: SOVIET BOMBER DAMAGED WHILE CARRYING SHUTTLE
articles.summary: A Soviet Bison bomber, carrying a shuttle orbiter piggyback, was damaged after a downwind landing incident caused it to run off the runway. Fortunately, the shuttle orbiter itself remained undamaged during the event.

articles.title: SATCOM 1R LAUNCHED
articles.summary: The RCA communications satellite, SATCOM 1R, was successfully launched on April 11 using a Delta 3924 booster. This new satellite is designed to have an operational lifespan of ten years.

articles.title: NOAA-8 SPACECRAFT STABELIZED
articles.summary: The NOAA-8 spacecraft, which had been tumbling since its March 28 launch from Vandenberg AFB, has now been successfully stabilized. Its primary mission involves monitoring global weather conditions and providing assistance to international search and rescue operations.

articles.title: SHUTTLE ENTERPRISE, TO TOUR EUROPE
articles.summary: The Space Shuttle Enterprise is scheduled to tour Europe atop its Boeing 747 carrier aircraft, with planned displays in Germany (Bonn-Cologne, May 21-23), France (Paris Airshow, May 26-June 5), and England (Stanstead, June 5-7). Although never intended for spaceflight, the Enterprise is vital for launch pad checkout work at Vandenberg AFB and will also stop in Ottawa, Canada, on its return journey.

articles.title: TDRS BEING MOVED TOWARD SYNCHRONOUS ORBIT
articles.summary: The Tracking Data Relay Satellite (TDRS), launched during the sixth shuttle flight, is undergoing orbital maneuvers to raise its orbit towards synchronous altitude after a failure of the Initial Upper Stage (IUS) left it in a low orbit. The IUS failure is under investigation, leading to the removal of a second TDRS from the upcoming eighth shuttle flight, which is now scheduled for August 11.

articles.title: PIONEER 10 PASSES PLUTO'S ORBIT
articles.summary: The Pioneer 10 spacecraft has now surpassed Pluto's orbit and is projected to cross Neptune's orbit on June 13. Launched 11 years ago, the probe remains operational and continues to send back data from the far reaches of the solar system.

articles.title: ARIANE SCHEDULED FOR JUNE LAUNCH
articles.summary: The sixth flight of the Ariane launch vehicle, initially set for June 3rd, is facing a potential delay. This is due to ground validation testing of the launcher's third stage falling behind schedule.

articles.title: BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article details the discovery and observation of two recent bright comets: Comet IRAS-Araki-Alcock (1983d) and Comet Sugano-Saigusa-Fujikawa (1983e). Comet IRAS-Araki-Alcock approached within 3 million miles of Earth, becoming naked-eye visible, and notably was the first comet officially named after a satellite. The author also discusses challenges in public viewing due to light pollution and mentions other periodic comets visible, along with communication methods for urgent astronomical news.

articles.title: PAST DISCOVERIES
articles.summary: This article details the discoveries of two comets by amateur astronomers in the Southern Hemisphere: Comet Austin (1982g) and Comet Bradfield (1979c). It describes the conditions and equipment used by Rodney Austin and William Bradfield for their respective finds, noting the extensive search hours and the celestial circumstances at discovery. The text also discusses missed opportunities for earlier discovery and highlights the dedication of these observers, particularly in the Southern Hemisphere.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Tempel 1 (1982j)
articles.summary: This article provides an ephemeris for Periodic Comet Tempel 1 (1982j) from late May to early July 1983, listing its right ascension, declination, and estimated magnitude. It notes the comet's path through Virgo, its approximate 3' diameter, and condensed appearance, referencing IAU Circular 3773.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Kopff (1982k)
articles.summary: This article provides observational data and characteristics for Periodic Comet Kopff (1982k) from late May to early July. The comet was observed to be around magnitude 9.5-10.0, displaying retrograde motion in the constellation Libra, and appearing as a diffuse object approximately 4 arcminutes in diameter. The observations were also referenced in IAU Circular 3779.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Tempel 2
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for Periodic Comet Tempel 2, detailing its celestial coordinates (Right Ascension, Declination) and estimated magnitude from May 26 to July 5. It describes the comet's trajectory as a straight-line path, moving from the constellation Pisces into Cetus. The data is sourced from IAU Circular 3794.

articles.title: Comet Comments Update
articles.summary: The article provides an updated ephemeris for Comet Sugano-Siagusa-Fujikawa (1983e), detailing its projected brightness and path for observers in June 1983, noting its close approach to Earth. It also outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) election process for its Board of Directors, explaining eligibility, nomination, and voting procedures while encouraging active member participation.

articles.title: WHILE THE TOWN BELOW SLEEPS, THE ASTRONOMER SWEEPS Some Thoughts about Early Morning Observing by Don Machholz
articles.summary: Don Machholz advocates for early morning astronomical observing, particularly for comet hunting, citing numerous benefits such as clearer, darker, and calmer skies, reduced artificial and natural light pollution, and better personal alertness. He details his routine of going to bed early and waking up in the pre-dawn hours to observe. The article emphasizes that early morning conditions often yield the most ideal observing opportunities.

articles.title: The Mid-July Messier Marathon
articles.summary: Don Machholz is organizing a Messier Marathon for July 9-10, following a previous clouded-out attempt, taking advantage of a new moon, warmer weather, and the visibility of approximately 98 Messier Objects. He invites participants to join him on Loma Prieta or observe from their own sites during the short summer night, also highlighting the presence of planets and the summer Milky Way.

articles.title: SJAA MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION/RENEWAL
articles.summary: This document is an application and renewal form for membership with the SJAA organization. It requests personal contact information, areas of interest, and offers three distinct membership tiers: Membership/S&T for $21.00, Junior (under 12) for $15.00, and Membership Only for $8.00.

articles.title: SIAA PPIHENS
articles.summary: This document appears to be a mailing label or header for "NEWS MATERIAL" from an entity identified as SIAA PPIHENS, located at 3509 CHILDPEAS, San Jose, CA. It indicates the material is time-sensitive and was sent via bulk rate U.S. postage.
